newsitem.title: USA: Dayton Hudson unit stops selling TVs, audio.
newsitem.headline: Dayton Hudson unit stops selling TVs, audio.

text.p: Dayton Hudson Corp said Wednesday it is phasing out the sale of large electronic items such as televisions and audio equipment in its department stores.
Sales of all such equipment will be fully discontinued by the end of January 1997.

Dayton Hudson spokeswoman Susan Eich said the step fits with company plans to focus on other areas of the home. "The electronics business has always been a challenge for us. This allows us to focus more on soft home furnishings and more lifestyle-oriented items. That is a key area for us, which is growing fast."
Selling floor space now used for TVs and stereo systems will be put to other use, Dayton Hudson said.
"We will use it to focus more on home decorating items such as linens, tabletop items, china and non-electronic home entertainment (goods)," Eich said.

Dayton Hudson dropped computers from its stores about two years ago "based upon the performance of that line," Eich said. Eich declined to discuss sales figures for the electronic equipment or to say how much the items contributed to the company's bottom line.
